title: BEWARE Ocado email scam: Fake mail sent to thousands and even robbed a family of £14,000
text:
People were this week sent fake shopping order emails from Ocado GETTY People who opened scam emails could have downloaded viscious malware 
The mother from Harrow said that she phoned Ocado customer service people and there were 40 people in the queue line ahead of her. When the 52-year-old finally got through the customer service agent told her not to open the attachment. But after telling the agent that she already had, Mrs Farmer said she was then told "there was nothing to worry about". Later that day the family's business account was cleared of its cash, and it wasn't until a computer engineer identified the fake Ocado email that Mrs Farmer realised what has happened. The mother is angry that Ocado did not put a notice on its site as soon as it realised that scammers were impersonating it and that customer service agents weren't better trained. Computer security expert Graham Cluley said: "Normally the malware will lurk on the victim's computer, waiting for them to log into their online bank account and grab the details at that point." Related articles Vauxhall Zafiras to be recalled after cars turned to terrifying... 
If Mrs Farmer had been advised that their computer had been given a virus they could have avoided using their online banking. She estimates that the cost of computer engineers and phone calls to sort the problem of the lost £14,000 has left her out of pocket by up to £2,000. Ocado has offered to make a goodwill gesture, but Mrs Farmer said it doesn't cover her costs. An Ocado spokesperson said: “We advise customers to be on guard for scams of this kind and be careful about opening attachments. "We also issued a warning on our website once the incident was made known to us. GETTY Scammers pretended to be from Ocado to get bank details 
“We have offered Ms Farmer a goodwill gesture as we regret that in this instance, the explanation of the fraudulent email given by our call centre did not live up to the high standards we set ourselves.”People who may have clicked on a phishing email can initially try to solve the problem with anti-virus. Mr Clueley said: "If the malware infected your computer you should try removing it with anti-virus software."If that has problems doing it, then you might need specialist help, for instance, contacting the tech support department of your anti-virus vendor, to recover."Alternatively you can wipe your computer and restore from a backup."
